00021 // @author Harley Gorrell
00022 // @brief  An example of file5 usage.

00044 // Just create the file.
00045 void example_create_file(const std::string& file_name)
00046 {
00047   // a pointer to a file5 object.
00048   // it isnt bound to a file yet.
00049   affx::File5_File* file5=new affx::File5_File();
00050   // Attempt to create a file with it.
00051   //
00052   try {
00053     file5->open(file_name,affx::FILE5_CREATE);
00054   }
00055   catch (...) {
00056     //
00057   }
00058   // even if not open, we can close it.
00059   file5->close();
00060   delete file5;
00061 }
00062 
00063 void example_open_file(const std::string& file_name)
00064 {
00065   // a pointer to a file5 object.
00066   // it isnt bound to a file yet.
00067   affx::File5_File* file5=new affx::File5_File();
00068   // Attempt to create a file with it.
00069   //
00070   try {
00071     file5->open(file_name,affx::FILE5_OPEN);
00072   }
00073   catch (...) {
00074     //
00075   }
00076   // even if not open, we can close it.
00077   file5->close();
00078   delete file5;
00079 }

00083 void example_write_tsv(const std::string& file_name,int num_rows)
00084 {
00085   // a pointer to a file5 object.
00086   // it isnt bound to a file yet.
00087   affx::File5_File* file5=new affx::File5_File();
00088 
00089   // This will be a new file
00090   file5->open(file_name,affx::FILE5_REPLACE);
00091 
00092   // "/tsv" is the same as "/tsv" because the tsv is the root group.
00093   affx::File5_Tsv* tsv5=file5->openTsv("tsv",affx::FILE5_REPLACE);
00094 
00095   int col_max=10;
00096 
00097   char colnamebuf[100];
00098   for (int cidx=0;cidx<col_max;cidx++) {
00099     sprintf(colnamebuf,"col-%02d",cidx);
00100     tsv5->defineColumn(0,cidx,colnamebuf,affx::FILE5_DTYPE_INT);
00101   }
00102 
00103   int val=0;
00104   for (int n=0;n<num_rows;n++) {
00105     for (int cidx=0;cidx<col_max;cidx++) {
00106       // set_i => sets the integer val (cause we dont want to fiddle with casting.)
00107       tsv5->set_i(0,cidx,val++);
00108     }
00109     tsv5->writeLevel(0);
00110   }
00111 
00112   //
00113   tsv5->close();
00114   delete tsv5;
00115 
00116   // even if not open, we can close it.
00117   file5->close();
00118   delete file5;
00119 }

00123 
00124 void example_read_tsv(const std::string& file_name,int max_print_rows)
00125 {
00126   // a pointer to a file5 object.
00127   // it isnt bound to a file yet.
00128   affx::File5_File* file5=new affx::File5_File();
00129 
00130   // This will be a new file
00131   file5->open(file_name,affx::FILE5_OPEN);
00132 
00133   // "/tsv" is the same as "/tsv" because the tsv is the root group.
00134   affx::File5_Tsv* tsv5=file5->openTsv("tsv");
00135 
00136   // how many columns are there?
00137   int col_max=tsv5->getColumnCount(0);
00138 
00139   // header rows
00140   std::string colname;
00141   for (int cidx=0;cidx<col_max;cidx++) {
00142     if (cidx!=0) {
00143       printf("\t");
00144     }
00145     tsv5->getColumnName(0,cidx,&colname);
00146     printf("%s",colname.c_str());
00147   }
00148   printf("\n");
00149 
00150   int val;
00151   tsv5->rewind();
00152   while (tsv5->nextLevel(0)==affx::FILE5_OK) {
00153     // limit the number of lines printed.
00154     if ((max_print_rows!=0)&&(tsv5->lineNum()>=max_print_rows)) {
00155       break;
00156     }
00157     // go across the current row and print the values.
00158     for (int cidx=0;cidx<col_max;cidx++) {
00159       if (cidx!=0) {
00160         printf("\t");
00161       }
00162       tsv5->get(0,cidx,&val);
00163       printf("%d",val);
00164     }
00165     printf("\n");
00166   }
00167 
00168   //
00169   tsv5->close();
00170   delete tsv5;
00171 
00172   // even if not open, we can close it.
00173   file5->close();
00174   delete file5;
00175 }

00178 
00179 void example_read_tsv_vec(const std::string& file_name)
00180 {
00181   // this is what we want to fill.
00182   std::vector<int> vector_to_fill;
00183 
00184   // This is just like the above.
00185   affx::File5_File* file5=new affx::File5_File();
00186   file5->open(file_name,affx::FILE5_OPEN);
00187   affx::File5_Tsv* tsv5=file5->openTsv("tsv");
00188 
00189   // this holds a ptr
00190   affx::File5_TsvColumn* colptr;
00191 
00192   // colptr will be null, we dont have that many columns.
00193   colptr=tsv5->getColumnPtr(0,999);
00194   assert(colptr==NULL);
00195 
00196   // now get the first column for real.
00197   colptr=tsv5->getColumnPtr(0,0);
00198   // Or you could use the the name as the second arg.
00199   // colptr=tsv5->getColumnPtr(0,"col-00");
00200   assert(colptr!=NULL);
00201 
00202   // Now for some magic. 
00203   // Remember that File5_TsvColumns are File5_vectors.
00204   // We get its size and adjust the vector we are going to fill.
00205   int col_len=colptr->size();
00206   vector_to_fill.resize(col_len);
00207   // now ask for it to be filled.
00208   // read_vector will try and put as many items as will fit.
00209   // Note that this might throw an exception of the data types dont match.
00210   // (we cant check that they match at compile time.)
00211   colptr->read_vector(0,&vector_to_fill);
00212   printf("read_tsv_vec: read: 1: %d of %d elements\n",
00213          int(vector_to_fill.size()),col_len);
00214   fflush(NULL);
00215   // Check the length is correct. (We know it should be this len.)
00216   assert(vector_to_fill.size()==col_len);
00217 
00218   // if the read is short, the vector is resized to what was 
00219   // able to be read -- in this case one element.
00220   colptr->read_vector(col_len-1,&vector_to_fill);
00221   printf("read_tsv_vec: read: %d of %d elements\n",
00222          int(vector_to_fill.size()), col_len);
00223   assert(vector_to_fill.size()==1);
00224 
00225   // close it, just like above.
00226   tsv5->close();
00227   delete tsv5;
00228   file5->close();
00229   delete file5;
00230 }

00234 // All our options are defined here to keep main more readable.
00235 void define_options(PgOptions* opts)
00236 {
00237   opts->setUsage("example-file5 -- A file5 test program.");
00238 
00239   opts->defOpt("h","help",PgOpt::BOOL_OPT,
00240                "Print this message.",
00241                "false");
00242   // file
00243   opts->defOpt("","create-file",PgOpt::STRING_OPT,
00244                "run the example file creation.",
00245                "");
00246   opts->defOpt("","open-file",PgOpt::STRING_OPT,
00247                "run the example file creation.",
00248                "");
00249   //
00250   opts->defOpt("","write-tsv",PgOpt::STRING_OPT,
00251                "",
00252                "");
00253   opts->defOpt("","read-tsv",PgOpt::STRING_OPT,
00254                "",
00255                "");
00256   opts->defOpt("","read-tsv-vec",PgOpt::STRING_OPT,
00257                "",
00258                "");
00259   opts->defOpt("","num-rows",PgOpt::INT_OPT,
00260                "",
00261                "100");
00262 }
00263 
00264 int main(int argc,const char* argv[]) {
00265   PgOptions* opts;
00266 
00267   // this needs to be called to init the File5 library.
00268   // (In turn it calls the HDF5 init function.)
00269   affx::File5_open();
00270 
00271   // throw our errors for testing.
00272   Err::setThrowStatus(true);
00273 
00274   // Create our option parser, define the options and parse.
00275   opts = new PgOptions;
00276   define_options(opts);
00277   opts->parseArgv(argv);
00278 
00279   // Print our help message if necessary.
00280   if (opts->getBool("help")) {
00281     opts->usage();
00282   }
00283   // figure out what the user wanted...
00284   else if (opts->get("create-file")!="") {
00285     example_create_file(opts->get("create-file"));
00286   }
00287   else if (opts->get("open-file")!="") {
00288     example_open_file(opts->get("open-file"));
00289   }
00290   else if (opts->get("write-tsv")!="") {
00291     example_write_tsv(opts->get("write-tsv"),opts->getInt("num-rows"));
00292   }
00293   else if (opts->get("read-tsv")!="") {
00294     example_read_tsv(opts->get("read-tsv"),opts->getInt("num-rows"));
00295   }
00296   else if (opts->get("read-tsv-vec")!="") {
00297     example_read_tsv_vec(opts->get("read-tsv-vec"));
00298   }
00299   else {
00300     opts->usage();
00301   }
00302 
00303   // delete the opts so valgrind doenst report them.
00304   delete opts;
00305 
00306   // for debugging with valgrind calling _exit will exit the program without
00307   // letting HDF5 clean up its memory.  This can help id memory leaks.
00308   // _exit(0);
00309 
00310   // Programs which use HDF5 should call this before exiting.
00311   // this cleans up resources it has allocated.
00312   affx::File5_close();
00313 
00314   return 0;
00315 }
